segment.source: This topic for the IT professional describes the Advanced Security Audit policy setting, Audit Kerberos Service Ticket Operations, which determines whether the operating system generates security audit events for Kerberos service ticket requests.
segment.target: This topic for the IT professional describes the Advanced Security Audit policy setting, Audit Kerberos Service Ticket Operations, which determines whether the operating system generates security audit events for Kerberos service ticket requests.

segment.source: Audit Kerberos Service Ticket Operations determines whether the operating system generates security audit events for Kerberos service ticket requests.
segment.target: Audit Kerberos Service Ticket Operations determines whether the operating system generates security audit events for Kerberos service ticket requests.

segment.source: Events are generated every time Kerberos is used to authenticate a user who wants to access a protected network resource.
segment.target: Events are generated every time Kerberos is used to authenticate a user who wants to access a protected network resource.

segment.source: Kerberos service ticket operation audit events can be used to track user activity.
segment.target: Kerberos service ticket operation audit events can be used to track user activity.

segment.source: Event volume: Very High on Kerberos Key Distribution Center servers.
segment.target: Event volume: Very High on Kerberos Key Distribution Center servers.

segment.source: This subcategory contains events about issued TGSs and failed TGS requests.
segment.target: This subcategory contains events about issued TGSs and failed TGS requests.

segment.source: Expected volume is very high on domain controllers.
segment.target: Expected volume is very high on domain controllers.

segment.source: IF - We recommend Success auditing, because you will see all Kerberos Service Ticket requests (TGS requests), which are part of service use and access requests by specific accounts.
segment.target: IF - We recommend Success auditing, because you will see all Kerberos Service Ticket requests (TGS requests), which are part of service use and access requests by specific accounts.

segment.source: Also, you can see the IP address from which this account requested TGS, when TGS was requested, which encryption type was used, and so on.
segment.target: Also, you can see the IP address from which this account requested TGS, when TGS was requested, which encryption type was used, and so on.

segment.source: For recommendations for using and analyzing the collected information, see the Security Monitoring Recommendations sections.
segment.target: For recommendations for using and analyzing the collected information, see the Security Monitoring Recommendations sections.

segment.source: We recommend Failure auditing, because you will see all failed requests and be able to investigate the reason for failure.
segment.target: We recommend Failure auditing, because you will see all failed requests and be able to investigate the reason for failure.

segment.source: You will also be able to detect Kerberos issues or possible attack attempts.
segment.target: You will also be able to detect Kerberos issues or possible attack attempts.

segment.source: This subcategory makes sense only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This subcategory makes sense only on domain controllers.

segment.source: This subcategory makes sense only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This subcategory makes sense only on domain controllers.

segment.source: 4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested.
segment.target: 4769(S, F): A Kerberos service ticket was requested.

segment.source: 4770(S): A Kerberos service ticket was renewed.
segment.target: 4770(S): A Kerberos service ticket was renewed.

segment.source: 4773(F): A Kerberos service ticket request failed.
segment.target: 4773(F): A Kerberos service ticket request failed.
